title: Tips Sheet on Data Security in OCHA's Data Management

outline.text: OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data
March 2022
INTRODUCTION
This tip sheet offers a set of recommended actions for data security in OCHA’s data management. All OCHA staff
PRACTICE GOOD PASSWORD MANAGEMENT
•	 Enable multi-factor authentication for all accounts.
•	 Do not reuse the same password for multiple accounts.
•	 Do not store your passwords physically (e.g. on notes) or digitally (in a file on your device) and do not share
•	 Do not enable the ’Remember Me’ functionality in applications and browsers.
•	 Change your passwords on your online accounts immediately if your device is lost or stolen.
USE ANTIVIRUS/ANTI-MALWARE SOFTWARE
•	 If you have questions about appropriate tools or how to configure them, check with the IT specialist in your
KEEP SOFTWARE AND OPERATING SYSTEMS UP-TO-DATE
•	 Use web browsers such as Chrome or Firefox that receive automatic security updates.
•	 Shut down devices at the end of the day to enable updating and protect against attacks.
AVOID PHISHING SCAMS AND BE CAREFUL WHAT YOU CLICK
•	 Do not reply to suspicious emails or forward them to your colleagues.
•	 Report any suspicious activity to abuse@un.org.

USE MOBILE DEVICES RESPONSIBLY
•	 Use approved messaging tools (such as Signal) that provide end-to-end encryption.
•	 Turn Bluetooth connectivity off when possible and minimize Bluetooth connectivity.
•	 Use a Virtual Private Network (VPN) when working online. The OICT Technology Standards includes two
•	 Always sign out of your account(s) if you are using a community computer or device.
•	 Disable biometric unlock features—particularly when in transit.
SAFEGUARD SENSITIVE DATA AND PRACTICE DATA MINIMIZATION
•	 Only collect the minimum amount of data is required to achieve the objective and purposes for a given data
•	 Only retain sensitive data for as long as necessary to fulfill the purpose for which it is being managed and as
•	 Transfer and store data using approved tools and channels (locally on an OCHA server, computer or laptop;
•	 Password protect files (Word, Excel, PDF) containing sensitive data and share document passwords through
•	 Limit and carefully monitor the number of people with access to sensitive data.
•	 Define a retention and destruction schedule for all data managed by OCHA and use appropriate tools for the
•	 Encrypt your email messages (using Outlook).
